lead_paragraph: Worried that an advantage in immigration law may end as the United States restores relations with their country, many Cubans have rushed off the island, only to be stalled in Central America.

byline.contributor: Azam Ahmed contributed reporting from Mexico City, and Julia Preston from New York.

headline.print_headline: Fearing Shift in Status, Cubans Rush for Exits and U.S.
headline.main: Cubans, Fearing Loss of Favored Status in U.S., Rush to Make an Arduous Journey

snippet: Worried that an advantage in immigration law may end as the United States restores relations with their country, many Cubans have rushed off the island, only to be stalled in Central America.
abstract: Many Cubans fear recent restoration of diplomatic ties between America and island will lead to repeal of 1966 Cuban Adjustment Act, which gives Cubans who arrive in United States a fast track to permanent legal residency; tens of thousands are risking their lives and savings in arduous journey through Central America to take advantage of privileged immigration process while it lasts.
